results.title: Sport and nutrition
results.creator_credit: Tom Trikojus and Video Education Australasia
results.brief_description: Elite sportspeople are becoming increasingly aware that nutrition is an integral component of their training and competition. This program provides an excellent summary of current nutritional practices for athletes. It looks at the requirements for training, competition and recovery, with a focus on three athletes: Liz Tadich (road cyclist), David Terek (soccer) and Lauren Burns (taekwondo). The program could also be used as a stimulus for further investigation into concepts such as: carbohydrate loading; pre-game meals; ergogenic aids - legal; designing diets for endurance and power athletes and Glycaemic index of foods. The video also examines the validity of the ‘fads, pills and potions’ which seem so common in elite sport today. Video support notes available. Suitable for Lower-Upper Secondary level students.

results.title: Sport and coaching
results.creator_credit: Tom Trikojus and Video Education Australasia
results.brief_description: This program covers the specific coaching skills, different styles and characteristics of a respected coach. Can they understand how to cater for different skill levels from the beginner through to the skilled athlete? The following topics relating to caching are covered: motivation to become a coach; philosophies of coaching; safety - the coaches’ role; planning and goal setting; physiological development of athletes; psychological aspects; management and administration duties; competition day - role of the coach; accreditation requirements for coaching; coaching and its unique challenges; coaches and athletes, the athletes’ view. Support notes available. Suitable for Lower-Upper Secondary level students.

results.title: Spook sport
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, Mary-Ellen Bute, Creative Film Society and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An expressionistic interpretation of “Danse macabre” by Camille Saint-Saens. Conventional cel animation and pen drawings were done by Norman McLaren directly on 35 mm film stock.

results.title: Spirits of the air, gremlins of the clouds
results.creator_credit: Alex Proyas, Andrew McPhail, Meaningful Eye Contact Film, MMA Films and Pro-image
results.brief_description: Felix Crabtree (Michael Lake) and his sister Betty (Rhys Davis) live in a dust blown shack admist a vast desert. Felix is a wheelchair bound “Dr. Strangelove” character, obsessed with flying, while Betty is paranoid, child-like, living in a world of her own, surrounded by religous relics and obsessed by the past. When a weatherbeaten fugitive named Smith (“The Norm”) staggers towards the homestead and collapses, Felix and Betty revive him. Felix learns that he and Smith share a desire to escape - Smith from his hunters and Felix from the dusty world he is forced to inhabit. They begin to build a flying machine to carry them to a new world but Felix soon realises that it is not just physical difficulties confining them to the desert.

results.title: Spirits of Havana
results.creator_credit: Bay Weyman, Luis O. Garcia, Peter Starr and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: ‘Spirits of Havana’ follows a pair of Canadian jazz players, Jane Bunnett and Larry Cramer, who trek annually to Cuba to collaborate with the local musicians there. Of course, like its recent antecedent, ‘Buena Vista Social Club’, ‘Spirits of Havana’ ends up celebrating the conviviality of Cuban people and culture and the integral role that music and rhythm plays in their lives. Shots of bustling Havana city streets or the bountiful Cuban countryside, overlaid with traditional Cuban music, punctuate this documentary and strongly hint at the Canadians’ love affair with this place. Extended recording sessions with a variety of local musicians from Bobby Carcasses, Amado Dedeu and Pancho Quinto to world famous Afro-Cuban rumba groups like Los Munequitos and Los Naranjos to Desandann, a Haitian group, reveal rich cross-cultural collaboration in action. The Canadians ensure it’s a two-way exchange when they carry out their educational and resource initiative by donating instruments to the local, under-resourced music conservatories and teach the students the world of jazz. Though lacking the cinematic splendour of ‘Buena Vista Social Club’, ‘Spirits of Havana’ is moving for its celebration of Cuban music, culture and history and for its testament to the possibility of cross-cultural understanding and exchange.

results.title: Spirited away (Special edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Hayao Miyazaki, Toshio Suzuki and Studio Ghibli
results.brief_description: Often referred to as the Japanese Walt Disney, it is soon obvious while watching master Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki’s “Spirited away” that the Disney reference point is mostly inadequate in understanding what you’re about to experience. Part mythic odyssey, part children’s fable, “Spirited away” is a wonderful and awe inspiring fantasy film that takes place in the most unexpected of places, a Japanese bathhouse for the gods. At the centre of this surreal world is Chihiro; a feisty ten year old girl who lands in this strange world when her parents decide to stop for a break at a seemingly abandoned amusement park on the way to their new home. In a classic fairytale touch, the parents greedily succumb to mystical temptations (in the form of a banquet of food which appropriately turns them into pigs), leaving the helpless Chihiro to fend for herself. With the onset of night, the amusement park transforms into a meeting place for spirits, demons and gods, which is ruled over by the crazed Yubaba. Chihiro must now find her place, learn the rules and earn her keep in this twilight world of stink gods, giant babies, witches and dragons. Like Miyazaki’s previous animation feature “Princess Mononoke”, “Spirited away” offers complex notions of good and evil, right and wrong, which is ultimately the main departure point between Miyazaki’s multilayered world and Walt Disney’s reassuring land of monochrome sentiment.

results.title: Spirit of the railway
results.brief_description: This moving documentary provides a personal journey through one of the most significant events in Australia’s history; the construction of the Thai-Burma railway. The railway was built by Australian prisoners of war and other allied and Asian laboueres during World War 2. The video uses personal accounts, forensic and historical footage, most of which hasn’t been seen in America, Australia or Japan. Features artwork by Ronald Searle, Jack Chalker, Ray Parkin and Fred Ransom-Smith.

results.title: Spinnolio
results.creator_credit: John Weldon, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Traditional folklore takes a wry turn in this animated tale about a carved wooden puppet who lacks mobility and human consciousness. Noted for his “cool head” and unruffled personality, the inanimate Spinnolio makes a totally passive, though quite successful go at life, until his employer decides to replace him with a computer. A modern-day fairy tale that smacks of the sardonic and has philosophical implications about the nature of consciousness, the work ethic, interpersonal relationships, and the citizen in society.
